repnme.cdata!:
Antigua and Barbuda; Dominica; Grenada; St.
            Kitts and Nevis; St. Lucia; St. Vincent and The Grenadines -
            OECS Ship-Generated Waste Management and Solid Waste
            Management Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, with a likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts, achieved through
            satisfactory Bank, and Borrower performances. Lessons
            Learned suggest that a regional approach provides for
            greater aid effectiveness in small island developing states,
            for it provides this aid effectiveness through economies of
            scale, and in turn, increases synergies in areas where
            resources, both human and financial, are limited. The
            regional approach can also help to effectively coordinate
            the dissemination and replication of lessons learned during
            implementation of country-specific components. Furthermore,
            the regional approach fosters a competitive environment
            between countries, providing benchmarks that inspire greater
            performance on a national level. Moreover, project
            components must have a built in flexibility, and realistic
            time table when dealing with multiple countries, with
            varying development capacities, and needs. Flexibility can
            be achieved through a demand-driven approach. In this
            project, the change to a demand-driven approach had a
            positive impact on implementation, as countries felt they
            could seek assistance to best fit their needs. Similarly,
            the provision for a Regional Coordinating Unit (RCU) is a
            useful method that facilitates project supervision for
            multiple country projects: the RCU in this project was able
            to provide key regional leadership, that ensured regional
            coordination, and consistency in approaches to solid waste
            management issues. Further lessons address the need for
            public awareness and education as essential in building
            support for major changes; balancing regional
            standardization, and potential efficiency gains, with
            country specific needs, to ensure the full benefits of a
            joint procurement; and, dealing with sub-national island
            systems, taken into account at the time of project design,
            as well as during implementation.
